--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Philip Tucker <ptucker@g...> wrote:
> > In SharpNEAT I opted for (2) as in Ken's implemenatation. My 
logic being
> > that I thought matching like innovations is beneficial but 
costly in
> > terms of CPU time. So I figured this gives a good balance. 
However I
> > just traced a bug whereby evolved networks where seen - by Ken - 
to have
> > multiple recurrent connections on a single node. I realise now 
that this
> > is a result of crossover between two genomes that contained the 
same
> > connection, but with a different innovation ID. To fix this I 
should
> > check for duplicate connections within genomes created by 
crossover,
> > which erodes some of the performance gain obtained from using 
technique
> > (2).
> 
> That's a good point.  How did you handle that case in your
> implementation, Ken?  If 2 chromosomes crossover where each has a
> connection between nodes 1 and 2, btu where the connections have
> different innovation IDs, do you sum the genotype weights to create
> the phenotype connection weight?  Or average them?  Or discard one?

I discarded one.  Only one gene that connects two nodes was allowed 
to make it into the offspring.

By the way, performance gains in crossover will have almost no 
effect on performance in general, so it's not really worth too much 
effort trying to optimize crossover.  In every experiment I've seen 
except the very simplest, NEAT takes up a tiny fraction of 
computation time.  It's the evaluations that are expensive.  

I'm not saying you shouldn't optimize your code.  I'm just saying 
making design decisions based on code efficiency in NEAT methods may 
not be the very helpful in the end.  Generally we can afford a 
little more expense if it leads to more meaningful operators or 
fewer evaluations in the long run.

ken
